meta.title: ‚ö° Process Task: Plan and Manage Schedule
meta.description: Flashcards for PMP Process Domain Task 8

flashcards.back: The sequence of activities that represents the longest path through the project, which determines the shortest possible duration. It has Zero Total Float.

The amount of time an activity can be delayed from its early start without delaying the planned project finish date.
Formula: LS - ES or LF - EF.
The amount of time an activity can be delayed without delaying the Early Start of any successor activity.
A significant point or event in a project. It has Zero Duration.

flashcards.front: What is the Precedence Diagramming Method (PDM)?
flashcards.back: A technique used for constructing a schedule model in which activities are represented by nodes and are graphically linked by one or more logical relationships to show the sequence. (Activity-on-Node).
An iterative planning technique in which the work to be accomplished in the near term is planned in detail, while the work in the future is planned at a higher level.
A logical relationship in which potential work cannot start until a predecessor activity finishes. (The most common type).
A relationship where a successor activity cannot start until a predecessor activity has started.
A relationship where a successor activity cannot finish until a predecessor activity has finished.
A relationship where a successor activity cannot finish until a predecessor activity has started. (Rare; e.g., the first shift cannot finish until the second shift starts).
The amount of time a successor activity will be delayed with respect to a predecessor activity. (Waiting time, e.g., paint drying).
The amount of time a successor activity can be advanced with respect to a predecessor activity. (Overlap, e.g., starting to write Chapter 2 before Chapter 1 is 100% finished).
A relationship that is contractually required or inherent in the nature of the work (e.g., must pour foundation before building walls).
A relationship that is established based on knowledge of best practices or some unusual aspect of the project. (e.g., "We prefer to paint the walls before installing the carpet").
A relationship between project activities and non-project activities (e.g., waiting for a government hearing). Usually outside the control of the team.
A relationship between project activities that are generally inside the project team's control.
A critical path method for calculating the Early Start and Early Finish dates by working forward through the schedule model.
A critical path method for calculating the Late Start and Late Finish dates by working backward through the schedule model.

flashcards.front: How do you calculate Project Diagram Duration?
flashcards.back: It is equal to the duration of the Critical Path.

flashcards.front: If an activity has Negative Float, what does it mean?
flashcards.back: The planned finish date is after the imposed deadline (e.g., the Customer requires it by Dec 1, but the schedule says Dec 5). The project is late before it starts.
Adding resources to critical path activities to shorten the schedule. It usually increases Cost (e.g., paying overtime).
Performing activities in parallel that were originally planned in sequence. It usually increases Risk (of rework).

flashcards.front: Does Crashing work on non-critical activities?
flashcards.back: No. Shortening a non-critical task does not shorten the project duration; it just increases the float of that task.

flashcards.front: What is the main risk of Fast Tracking?
flashcards.back: Rework. If you start the foundation before the blueprints are approved, you might have to tear it up later.

flashcards.front: Scenario: You are behind schedule. You have no extra money. Which compression technique is viable?
flashcards.back: Fast Tracking. (Crashing requires money).

flashcards.front: Scenario: You are behind schedule. The deadline is firm. You have budget reserves. Which technique is viable?
flashcards.back: Crashing. (It's safer than Fast Tracking if you have the cash).
A technique in which start and finish dates are adjusted based on resource constraints. It typically lengthens the schedule.

A technique that adjusts the activities of a schedule model such that the requirements for resources on the project do not exceed certain predefined resource limits. It operates only within the limits of Float, so it does not change the project end date.

flashcards.front: What is the Law of Diminishing Returns in Crashing?
flashcards.back: Adding more resources eventually yields less output per unit (e.g., too many cooks in the kitchen). Crashing isn't linear.

flashcards.front: What is Monte Carlo Analysis for Schedule?
flashcards.back: A simulation that runs thousands of possible project scenarios to calculate the probability of finishing by a certain date.

flashcards.front: What is the primary unit of schedule planning in Scrum?
flashcards.back: The Sprint (or Iteration), typically 1-4 weeks long.
A measure of the amount of work a team can tackle during a single Sprint (e.g., 20 Story Points).
A high-level schedule that indicates which features will be available at the end of each release (which may span multiple Sprints).
A graphical representation of work left to do versus time. Ideally, it trends down to zero by the end of the Sprint/Project.
A chart showing the total scope (work to be done) and the work completed. It is useful for showing when scope is added (the total scope line rises).
Setting a fixed time period for an activity (e.g., a one-hour meeting, a two-week sprint). If work isn't done, the box still closes.
Changing the plan as new information becomes available (Agile Principle: Responding to change over following a plan).

flashcards.front: How do you calculate Sprints Required?
flashcards.back: Total Story Points in Backlog / Average Velocity. (e.g., 100 points / 20 points per sprint = 5 Sprints).
A 15-minute timeboxed event for the Development Team to synchronize activities and create a plan for the next 24 hours.
Generally No. Agile focuses on flow and prioritizing the backlog rather than a strict dependency network, although dependencies still exist.

flashcards.front: Scenario: An activity has Total Float of 5 days and Free Float of 2 days. If you delay it by 4 days, what happens?
flashcards.back: It creates a delay for the successor, but the Project End Date is safe. (Passed Free Float limit, but within Total Float limit).

flashcards.front: Scenario: The client demands a change that adds 2 days to a critical path activity. What is the impact?
flashcards.back: The project end date acts delayed by 2 days (unless you Compress).

flashcards.front: Scenario: A team member suggests doing two tasks at once to catch up. What is this called?
flashcards.back: Fast Tracking.

flashcards.front: Scenario: You are estimating a task where you have no historical data. Which method is best?
flashcards.back: Three-Point Estimating (or Expert Judgment).

flashcards.front: Scenario: You are estimating a task where you have tons of data and it's very repetitive (e.g., installing 1000 standard windows). Which method is best?
flashcards.back: Parametric Estimating.

flashcards.front: Scenario: A resource is over-allocated, but you cannot delay the project finish date. Which optimization technique do you use?
flashcards.back: Resource Smoothing. (It only adjusts non-critical activities).

flashcards.front: Scenario: Your Burndown chart has a "flat line" for 5 days. What does this mean?
flashcards.back: No work was completed/closed during those 5 days.

flashcards.front: Scenario: The customer wants to move the deadline up by 2 weeks. What is the first thing you check?
flashcards.back: The Critical Path. You need to see which activities drive the duration to know if it's feasible.

flashcards.front: Scenario: An activity on the Critical Path is completed 2 days early. What happens to the project float?
flashcards.back: The project now has 2 days of positive float (or forces an earlier finish).

flashcards.front: Scenario: You are managing a software project. A developer says "I can't start the UI until the API is done." What dependency is this?
flashcards.back: Finish-to-Start (FS). It is likely a Mandatory dependency (Hard Logic).

flashcards.front: Calculate Standard Deviation (Sigma): O=2, M=5, P=14.
Network: A (3 days) -> B (4 days). What is the duration?
flashcards.back: 3 + 4 = 7 days.

flashcards.front: Network: Start connects to A (5 days) and B (7 days). Both connect to End. What is the Critical Path duration?
flashcards.back: 7 days (Path B is longer).

flashcards.front: Using the previous card (A=5, B=7), what is the Float of Activity A?
flashcards.back: 7 - 5 = 2 days.

flashcards.front: Estimate Range: If Mean is 20 and Sigma is 2. What is the range for 95% confidence? (2 Sigma).
What is the Schedule Management Plan?
flashcards.back: A component of the project management plan that establishes the criteria and the activities for developing, monitoring, and controlling the schedule.
The approved version of a schedule model that can be changed only through formal change control procedures and is used as a basis for comparison to actual results.
A documented tabulation of schedule activities that shows the activity description, activity identifier, and a sufficiently detailed scope of work description.
Data about the activity (e.g., codes, predecessor activities, successor activities, logical relationships, leads and lags, resource requirements, imposed dates, constraints).
A graphical representation of the logical relationships, also referred to as dependencies, among the project schedule activities.
Aggregating the estimates of the lower-level components of the WBS (activity durations) to get the total project duration.
"Work expands to fill the time available for its completion." (Reason to avoid padding estimates).
Planned procrastination. People start to apply themselves only at the last possible moment before the deadline.

flashcards.front: What is the Critical Chain Method?
flashcards.back: A schedule method that allows the project team to place buffers on any project schedule path to account for limited resources and project uncertainties. (Focuses on Resource constraints, not just Logic).
Adding buffers (Contingency Reserves) to the schedule to account for uncertainty/risk.

flashcards.front: True or False: A project can have multiple Critical Paths.
flashcards.back: True. If two paths have the exact same duration and are the longest, both are critical. (This increases Risk).

flashcards.front: True or False: Milestones have duration.
flashcards.back: False. Milestones are zero-duration points in time.

flashcards.front: True or False: Backward Pass calculates Early Start.
flashcards.back: False. Backward Pass calculates Late Start (LS) and Late Finish (LF).

flashcards.front: True or False: A Fast-Tracked schedule usually has higher cost.
flashcards.back: False. It has higher Risk. Crashing has higher Cost.
An Agile voting technique to gauge consensus/confidence in an estimate (1 finger = no way, 5 fingers = easy).
An Agile estimation technique using cards (Fibonacci sequence) to estimate effort/relative size of user stories.
Estimating tasks in comparison to one another (e.g., Story Points, T-Shirt Sizes) rather than absolute time (Hours).
A bar chart that tracks tasks across time. Good for tracking progress.
Looking 3-6 months out to determine when product increments will be released to customers.
A Pull-based system (like Kanban) where work is pulled from a backlog only when resources are available, rather than being scheduled in advance.
